data.title: OneMain Holdings Non-GAAP EPS of $1.90 beats by $0.30, revenue of $1.24B in-line
data.description:
• OneMain Holdings press release (OMF): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $1.90 beats by $0.30.
  • Revenue of $1.24B (+6.0% Y/Y) in-line.
  • 3 Q 2025 Managed receivables of $25.9 billion.
  • Raised quarterly dividend by 1% to $1.05 per share.
  • Board of Directors approves $1.0 billion share repurchase program.
  • The provision for finance receivable losses was $488 million in the third quarter of 2025, down $24 million compared to the prior year period.
  • During the third quarter of 2025, the allowance for finance receivable losses increased $60 million driven by growth in receivables.

data.title: Civeo Corporation GAAP EPS of -$0.04 misses by $0.08, revenue of $170.5M misses by $3.04M
data.description:
• Civeo Corporation press release (CVEO): Q3 GAAP EPS of -$0.04 misses by $0.08.
  • Revenue of $170.5M (-3.3% Y/Y) misses by $3.04M.

  • For the full year of 2025, Civeo is tightening its previously provided revenue and Adjusted EBITDA guidance ranges to $640 million to $655 million and $86 million to $91 million, respectively.

    The Company is maintaining its full year 2025 capital expenditure guidance range of $20 million to $25 million.

data.title: Valaris anticipates 90% drillship utilization by end of 2026 as backlog climbs to $4.5B
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Valaris Limited (VAL) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Anton Dibowitz, President and CEO, opened the call by emphasizing "another strong quarter of financial results with meaningful EBITDA and free cash flow generation." He highlighted the successful execution of Valaris' commercial strategy, including a contract for VALARIS DS-12 with BP Offshore Egypt, ensuring all four drillships with near-term availability are now booked for 2026.

  • Dibowitz explained that "demand for offshore drilling services is developing as we expected" and described a "robust pipeline of deepwater opportunities for our high-specification fleet," with advanced customer discussions underway for rigs completing contracts in the second half of 2026.

  • A key operational highlight was a fleet-wide revenue efficiency of 95% for Q3, supported by strong safety milestones across several rigs.

  • Matt Lyne, Senior VP & Chief Commercial Officer, noted that "since our second quarter call, we've secured new contracts and extensions, adding nearly $200 million to our contract backlog" and that the current total backlog stands at $4.5 billion. He detailed a $140 million contract for VALARIS DS-12 with BP offshore Egypt, expected to commence in mid-Q2 2026.

  • Christopher Weber, Senior VP & CFO, stated, "total revenues were $596 million compared to $615 million in the prior quarter, primarily due to fewer operating days for our floater fleet as drillships VALARIS DS-15 and DS-18 completed contracts midway through the third quarter without immediate follow-on work." He also reported "adjusted EBITDA was $163 million compared to $201 million in the prior quarter."

Outlook

  • Management expects Q4 total revenues in the range of $495 million to $515 million, down from $596 million in Q3, due to fewer operating days across the fleet. Q4 adjusted EBITDA is projected between $70 million and $90 million, with CapEx of $145 million to $165 million.

  • The midpoint of Q4 guidance implies "expected full year adjusted EBITDA of approximately $625 million, which is roughly $40 million above the midpoint of guidance we provided on our second quarter call" (CFO Weber).

  • Dibowitz reiterated confidence in industry recovery, stating, "we anticipate seventh-generation drillships will exit 2026 with utilization levels around 90%."

Financial Results

  • Q3 total revenues were $596 million, a decrease from the prior quarter, attributed to fewer operating days in the floater fleet. Adjusted EBITDA was $163 million, above the guidance range of $120 million to $140 million, driven by certain contracts running longer, higher ARO leased rig revenues, and lower support costs.

  • Adjusted free cash flow was $237 million, with $198 million in operating cash flow. The company repurchased $75 million of shares during the quarter. Cash and cash equivalents at quarter-end were $676 million.

  • CapEx for Q3 totaled $70 million, below guidance due to timing; the company expects full-year CapEx to be about $390 million.

Q&A

  • Scott Gruber, Citigroup: Asked about the appetite for further share repurchases. CFO Weber replied, "We executed the $75 million of repurchases in the quarter...we're going to be opportunistic, and that's what you saw this quarter."

  • Gruber asked about minimum cash needed for operations. Weber stated "around $200 million to run the business."

  • Gruber inquired about increased exploration activity. Dibowitz responded, "we do see an increase in exploration discussions...the consensus is that we're going to need additional developments in order to meet the world's energy needs."

  • Gregory Lewis, BTIG: Queried asset sales as part of shareholder returns. Dibowitz explained, "our capital return needs to be driven by delivering operational cash flow...the ability to sell assets when there are attractive opportunities, it is just opportunistic over and above that."

  • Eddie Kim, Barclays: Raised concerns about day rates for seventh-gen drillships. Dibowitz said, "we believe the market is playing out as we expected. I think that day rates for high-spec ships have largely troughed in the high 300s, kind of low to mid -400 range."

  • Doug Becker, Capital One: Asked about Petrobras discussions. Lyne stated, "Petrobras are looking across their entire value supply chain for potential savings in 2026...they want to maintain their production targets, which means they are likely to maintain a fleet of similar size over the long term."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for further details on share repurchases, asset sales, and contract day rate trends, expressing slightly cautious optimism but noting concerns about near-term cash flow and day rates.

  • Management maintained a confident and disciplined tone, emphasizing operational performance and commercial achievements, using phrases like "we remain committed" and "we expect."

  • Compared to last quarter, management’s tone remained confident, but analysts were slightly more pressing regarding shareholder returns and market recovery timing.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for full-year adjusted EBITDA increased by $40 million from the previous quarter’s midpoint.

  • Management now reports all four drillships with near-term availability are contracted for 2026, compared to three last quarter.

  • Total backlog decreased from $4.7 billion to $4.5 billion, while contract awards since last quarter totaled nearly $200 million.

  • Analysts continued to focus on shareholder returns, day rates, and contract coverage, with management reiterating discipline and operational strength.

  • Management’s sentiment remained confident, with a slightly more constructive tone on exploration and market recovery.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited "near-term commodity price uncertainty" but underscored a robust pipeline for deepwater opportunities.

  • Petrobras cost discussions introduce uncertainty for 2026, though management expects fleet size to remain stable.

  • Potential for some day rates to remain below $400,000, particularly in lower OpEx environments.

  • Analysts flagged concerns about gap-fill work for idle rigs and the risk of white space in the schedule.

Final Takeaway

Valaris management emphasized operational excellence, commercial execution, and disciplined cost management as the foundation for ongoing shareholder value creation. The company reported strong EBITDA and free cash flow, expanded contract coverage into 2026, and expressed confidence in robust deepwater demand, targeting high utilization for its drillship fleet by the end of 2026. Management reiterated a commitment to shareholder returns, driven primarily by operational cash flow and opportunistic asset sales, while monitoring market developments and maintaining financial flexibility.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Nexperia supply halt in China deepens chip shortage fears for automakers - Reuters
data.description:
Dutch chipmaker Nexperia has halted wafer supplies to its Chinese assembly plant in Dongguan, citing the local unit’s failure to meet contractual payment terms, according to a letter to its customers seen by Reuters.

The suspension, effective October 26, follows escalating tensions after the Dutch government seized control of Nexperia from China’s Wingtech Technology on September 30 and removed its Chinese CEO over security concerns.

Nexperia’s Chinese unit had recently resumed chip deliveries to local customers but demanded payments in yuan instead of foreign currencies. In its letter, Nexperia said it could no longer justify shipments and would seek alternative supply solutions to support customers.

While denying any plan to withdraw from China, Nexperia stressed its financial independence from Wingtech. The dispute adds to global supply chain worries, with Stellantis (STLA) saying that it is monitoring the supply situation and Nissan (OTCPK:NSANY) (OTCPK:NSANF) warning its chip stockpile would last only through early November.

German auto giant Volkswagen (OTCPK:VWAGY) (OTCPK:VWAPY) has already warned of production stoppages amid China’s export restrictions on semiconductors made by Nexperia.

Prices for some Nexperia chips in China have reportedly surged more than tenfold in recent weeks.

data.title: Broadstone Net Lease raises 2025 AFFO per share guidance to $1.49-$1.50 amid robust build-to-suit momentum
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Broadstone Net Lease (BNL) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO John Moragne reported a "strong quarter of results that reflects the continued success of our differentiated growth strategy as well as the deep expertise and strategic acumen of our team." He highlighted investments of $204 million in acquisitions and development projects, full rent collection, and resolution of the At Home and Claire’s tenant situations, with no bad debt incurred. Moragne announced a sequential quarterly contractual rental obligation growth of 1.2% and a 5.7% increase in quarterly AFFO per share compared to Q3 2024. He stated, "we are raising our full year 2025 guidance to $1.49 to $1.50 of AFFO per share, representing 4.2% to 4.9% growth for the year."

  • Moragne discussed $552.6 million year-to-date investments, including $353.4 million in new acquisitions, $150.2 million in build-to-suit developments, $40.7 million in transitional capital, and $8.3 million in revenue-generating capex. The weighted average initial cash capitalization rate for new property acquisitions was 7.1%, with a straight-line yield of 8.2%. He noted, "the estimated returns in our build-to-suit pipeline are even better, standing at 7.5% on an initial cash capitalization rate basis and 8.9% on a straight-line basis."

  • The company completed a $350 million public offering of 5% senior unsecured notes due in 2032, which was nearly 7x oversubscribed. Moragne said, "we have delivered total shareholder return of more than 30% since the beginning of 2023" and "year-to-date, we've delivered total shareholder return of nearly 20%."

  • President and COO Ryan Albano described a build-to-suit pipeline expected to deliver approximately $28 million of additional ABR between Q4 2025 and the end of 2026, representing 6.7% growth in current ABR. Eight in-process developments comprise $370.9 million, with average initial yield of 7.5% and straight-line yield of 8.9%, and weighted average lease term of 13.1 years.

  • CFO Kevin Fennell stated, "During the quarter, we generated adjusted funds from operations of $74.3 million or $0.37 per share, in line with the prior quarter and a 5.7% increase over Q3 of last year." He noted core G&A totaled $7.4 million for the quarter and $21.7 million year-to-date. Fennell added, "we ended the quarter with pro forma leverage of 5.4x net debt, approximately $38 million of unsettled equity and over $900 million available on our revolver."

Outlook

  • The company raised 2025 per share guidance to a range of $1.49 to $1.50, reflecting expected investment volume between $650 million and $750 million, and disposition volume between $75 million and $100 million. Disposition expectations include identified transactions already occurred or expected by year-end. Management expects "little to no bad debt to close out the year."

  • Moragne indicated confidence in the industrial-focused strategy and build-to-suit program, citing e-commerce and reshoring as long-term growth drivers, with opportunities geographically centered on logistics hubs.

Financial Results

  • Broadstone reported adjusted funds from operations of $74.3 million or $0.37 per share for the quarter. Core G&A totaled $7.4 million for the quarter and $21.7 million year-to-date. The company reported 99.5% leased at quarter end and 100% rent collection for all properties under lease, a 90-basis point increase compared to Q3 2024. The weighted average initial cash cap rate for new acquisitions was 7.1%, with straight-line yield of 8.2%. Subsequent to quarter end, an additional $103.2 million in acquisitions closed, with $67 million under control for Q4.

  • The $350 million 5% senior unsecured notes issuance was used to pay down the revolver balance, maintaining ample liquidity.

Q&A

  • John Kim, BMO Capital Markets, asked about the preference between capital recycling and holding build-to-suit assets. CEO Moragne responded, "It's certainly not preferred. I'd like to joke that these are our babies. We're growing them up. We'd love to hold on to them for the long term...Our plan is to make sure that we can control our destiny. And if we need to sell off some of these assets and capture the upside, not only is that going to be a great source of capital...it also helps prove out the concept."

  • Upal Rana, KeyBanc, inquired about criteria for issuing equity. Moragne answered, "That's a little bit of both, but we lean more towards the opportunity set and looking at what the incremental cost of capital is relative to the investment pipeline."

  • Anthony Paolone, JPMorgan, questioned lease expirations through 2027. Moragne stated, "Nothing material. The executions that we've had so far this year have been really good. We've been at like 108% from leases that we have executed...and are having advanced discussions with those folks for '26 and even some for '27."

  • Caitlin Burrows, Goldman Sachs, asked about transitional capital investments and funding strategies. Management described the retail investment as "less than $1 million" and the industrial project as intended for a future build-to-suit, with "lots of upside" and ongoing tenant interest.

  • Ronald Kamdem, Morgan Stanley, queried about acquisition volume and cap rates. Management noted product supply remains muted, competition is fierce, and cap rates have "plateaued a little bit." Construction costs have increased, mainly affecting hard costs, but have not impacted the economics of their projects.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on capital recycling, funding strategy, lease rollover, competition, and tenant credit, indicating a slightly positive to neutral tone, with questions focused on execution consistency, upside realization, and risk management.

  • Management maintained a confident and disciplined tone in both prepared remarks and Q&A, emphasizing strong execution, flexibility, and growth visibility. Phrases such as "we feel good about where we are headed" and "we believe there's still a lot of share price valuation upside" indicated high confidence.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remains confident, while analysts’ tone shifted slightly more positive due to improved execution on tenant credit and guidance raise.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for AFFO per share was raised from a midpoint of $1.49 in Q2 to a range of $1.49-$1.50 in Q3, with investment volume guidance increased at the midpoint by $100 million.

  • Tenant credit concerns have been resolved for At Home and Claire’s, with no bad debt incurred in Q3, compared to ongoing uncertainty in Q2.

  • Lease collection and occupancy improved, with rent collection reaching 100% and occupancy at 99.5% versus 99.1% in the prior quarter.

  • The tone shifted from addressing lingering concerns in Q2 to highlighting proven execution and value creation in Q3.

Risks and Concerns

  • Competitive acquisition environment and muted product supply could impact deal flow and pricing.

  • Construction and labor costs have increased, though management reported no material impact on project economics.

  • Management closely monitors the home furnishing sector, casual dining, and tenants with near-term debt maturities, but no material individual tenant risks were cited for 2026.

Final Takeaway

Broadstone Net Lease’s third quarter results demonstrated continued execution on its differentiated build-to-suit strategy, robust acquisition activity, and effective tenant risk management, leading to a raised full-year AFFO guidance and strong balance sheet flexibility. Management emphasized confidence in delivering sustained growth and shareholder value, supported by a well-leased portfolio, full rent collection, and a pipeline aligned with long-term industrial and logistics tailwinds.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Euro Area inflation eases to 2.1% in October
data.description:
The inflation rate in the Euro Area decreased to 2.10% in October from 2.20% in September of 2025. 

The Consumer Price Index increased 0.2% M/M in October 2025, following a 0.1% rise in September, preliminary estimates showed.

Currency: (EUR:USD)

data.title: Solidion Technology regains Nasdaq compliance, shares rise
data.description:
• Solidion Technology (STI) was notified by NASDAQ staff that it had regained compliance with NASDAQ's market value listing requirements, the company said on Friday.
  • As a result, all matters pertaining to NASDAQ deficiencies are now closed.
  • Solidion Technology (STI) up 3% in premarket trading.

data.title: Corbus Pharmaceuticals slumps 17%, prices $75M at $13 per share
data.description:
• Corbus Pharmaceuticals (CRBP) priced an underwritten public offering of ~4.74M shares at $13.00 per share and pre-funded warrants to purchase ~1.03M shares, for a total public offering size of ~$75M.
  • The underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 865,384 shares of its common stock on the same terms and conditions.
  • The offering is expected to close on or about November 3, 2025.
  • Corbus intends to use the net proceeds of the offering to fund the clinical development of its pipeline and for working capital and other general corporate purposes.
  • The stock price dropped ~17% on Friday during pre-market hours of trading.
